div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: Scene.—Interior of saloon, in the Château Beauregard, opening into Conservatory—the saloon is richly decorated, style Louis Quinze—panels—ceiling—screens, painted àla Watteau or Boucher—stands of flowers—tables—couches—statuettes, &c., &c. (all light and elegant) scattered about—mirrors reflect and give depth to scene—the conservatory full of plants in flower, their brilliancy of colour relieved and softened by several statues on pedestals.
Plumeau, in handsome livery, discovered dusting furniture with feather brush.

sp.speaker: Plum.
sp.p: There! I think I've done enough for to day. I wasn't born to work; that's a fact. When madame hired me in Paris, it was distinctly understood, I was for ornament; but now we're down in the country, she looks for utility. She'll be disappointed. (dusting statue down stage, L.) So this is Apoller, as is spoken of for his figger. Bah! put Apoller in livery, I should like to see how he'd look then. (complacently) It's the uniform as tests the man. (moves about, still dusting) I wonder what made the countess quit Paris in such a hurry. Since old Count Beauregard did the amiable thing, leaving madame, young, rich, and a widder, she's been as capricious as the new barometer, that Mr. Copernicus Kopp has just hung up in the hall, which sticks to nothing but change, and must be studied by the rules of contrairy. (throwing himself on couch, R.) Now, if I was a rich young widder, I'd—

sp.speaker: Fichu.
sp.p: This way—this way!Fichu enters, L.Lor! Monsieur Plumeau, is that you?

sp.speaker: Plum.
sp.p: Yes, Madame Fichu, it's as much as is left of me. I find the country air too exhausting. Early rising and regular habits are killing me. You were speaking to something when you entered—one of the natives, I presume?

sp.speaker: Fichu.
sp.p: Monsieur Molasse's servant.

sp.speaker: Plum.
sp.p: The retired grocer! (rising languidly) Really, if madame isn't a little more choice in her acquaintance, I must resign.

sp.speaker: Fichu.
sp.p: Hush! (turning to door, L.) Come in, Monsieur Mouton.
sp.stage: Mouton, a peasant, long hair, sheepish face, high collared short waisted coat—comes stamping in, L.—he wears sabots.

sp.speaker: Mout.
sp.p: Here I am. (he comes a little down stage, then halts in wonderment at the gorgeous appearance of Plumeau) Well, I never!

sp.speaker: Plum.
sp.p: I suppose not. (walking round and surveying him superciliously) How wonderful are the works of nature. (posing before Mouton) Don't often see a person like me in these parts?

sp.speaker: Mout.
sp.p: No; I've only seen one before, an' he were jack-pudding to a travelling doctor.

sp.speaker: Plum.
sp.p: Barbarian!

sp.speaker: Fichu.
sp.p: Don't stand there with your mouth like a round O in a copy book, and all your fingers pointing different ways like a sign post. What are you afraid of?

sp.speaker: Mout.
sp.p: I a'n't afraid. I'm 'stonished, that's all. I'm always 'stonished. (laughing sheepishly) It's a way I've got. (pulling out note) Here's the compliments of Monsieur and Madame Molasse, an' they'll be here in an hour, to wait upon the Countess Beauregard.

sp.speaker: Fichu.
sp.p: One would think you read it.

sp.speaker: Mout.
sp.p: O' course I have; I'd nothing else to do on the road.

sp.speaker: Plum.
sp.p: Good—very good—the brute has parts, if cultivated. (laughter in conservatory at back) The Countess! it's really too bad. You don't hear such laughter as that in Paris—very coarse merriment, very.
sp.stage: Exit, L. with gesture of despair, as the Countess and Julie D'Aumont, enter from conservatory; the former, coquettishly attired in a semi-Arcadian (demi-Watteau costume)—the latter in rich travelling toilette—the Countess eating cherries.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Laugh on, dear, I am always happy to contribute to the amusement of my friends.

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: Don't be angry, Clare; but I must laugh, to think that I should have met that pearl of fashion, and queen of ton the Countess Beauregard, perched upon the back of a shambling donkey, between two baskets of cherries, one on each side, to preserve her balance.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p:
I confess the donkey, but deny the
shamble. Fatigued with a long walk, I accepted the offer of a good-natured peasant woman, and was returning home in true Arcadian fashion, when, to my joyful surprise, I met you. (taking both Julie's hands) Tell me to what lucky chance I am indebted for this visit, which I hope to make a long one?

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: A chance indeed. I was on my way to join our old friend, the Baroness d'Antin, who is holding quite a little court of her own at Eaudouce.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: The bathing place a dozen miles from here?

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: Exactly. But halting to change horses at this village, I heard by accident, that you were the owner of this estate; and so, dear friend and schoolfellow, I renounced the Baroness for a time and—am here.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Nor shall you speedily depart.

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: It is now my turn to put a question. May I ask the reason of your sudden disappearance from society and Paris?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I have but a woman's reason to offer—caprice!

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: Which, of course, as a woman, I am slow to believe. I suspect an affair of the heart!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Heart. My dear Julie, you are talking of society and Paris, where such an adjunct to one's anatomy is found only in a fossil state, preserved in cabinets of curiosities.

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: Yet all the world said—

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Nothing worth listening to, be assured. Ah, Julie, the little of belief still left to society is reserved for calumny alone.

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: But—

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Seized with a sudden disgust for the artificial, I resolved upon studying the natural, so placing those two curious specimens of art, Fichu and Plumeau, outside my travelling carriage, I mounted inside, and somehow—I scarcely know how—found my way here.

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: A delightful place!—but the natives?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: A most docile race, that from living in continual companionship with the cattle have caught much of their dumbness and placidity. When any of the inhabitants do make a descent upon you—they either sit silent for hours like a circle of Druidical stones, or all open upon you at once like a kennel of hounds at feeding time.

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: You, at least, have not changed.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I'd a visit from one of the chiefs of the tribe only this morning, and he sat staring at me thus—with a face round and blank as a Dutch clock, and, to complete the simile, he only sounded twice within the hour, once to tell me the time of day, and once to instruct me as to the probable state of the weather.

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p:
But you have another neighbour of whom you have
not yet told me—the proprietor of that white house which overlooks the river.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: The General Lacroix.

sp.speaker: Julie.
Countess.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: Is he here?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: The general—

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: No! Felicien.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: Nothing—only the clouds are beginning. to disperse. (her manner changes into one of affectionate kindness) Clare! Clare! you must not attempt to deceive me. All Paris talked of Felicien's love for you.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: All Paris was mistaken then.

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: Of one thing I am sure. Pardon the frankness of a friend—almost of a sister—but—

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: You loved him.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I?

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: Nay—I will spare you the pain of an avowal—that blush is more eloquent than words.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Well then, I loved him—(she takes Julie's hands) and I love him still!

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: And he?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Loves me no longer.

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: Is it possible—has another usurped?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Oh, no, no; I am sure of that! (with a growing agitation) yet I will be satisfied—and I have a means!

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: What means?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: His uncle.

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: General Lacroix!—a confirmed woman-hater!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: But now a captive to my bow and spear.

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: The lion in love? impossible!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Hopelessly entangled. (they both laugh) In his noble simplicity of heart he sees nothing that is passing around him, and believes that his nephew and I have met here for the first time—seeing this, and irritated—justly irritated—by Felicien's change of manner and strange indifference, I determined to—

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: Play the uncle against the nephew?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: A freak, and I almost fear a foolish one—yet it is the only test—for without jealousy (she sighs) there is no love.

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: A lover of sixty! Cupid repudiates the idea.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Don't be alarmed, neither Cupid nor Hymen are likely to involve themselves in this matter—on one side at least.

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: You will fail, or General Lacroix is sadly belied by his reputation.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: A word of mine, and this scorner of a woman is at my feet. You shake your head! Come, I will wager this bracelet, which you were admiring so much, against your tablets, or what you will—that in a week, nay, this very day, I will draw from our man-of-war a declaration, and that in due form.

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: The witness?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Yourself! It is for the credit of our sex I break a lance. Come, and while you make your toilette, we will organize the attack.

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: And the enemy?

sp.speaker: Voice.
sp.p: Announce, General Hercules Lacroix!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Hush! he is here!
sp.stage: (they escape by door, R. laughing, as General Lacroix appears in conservatory preceded by Plumeau, to whom as he enters, he gives a vigorous push with his walking cane)

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: General Lacroix! are you asleep? sleeping at your post is death by all the articles of war. (striking cane upon ground and coming down stage) Thunder! here's a name that I've borne for sixty years and more, and yet it's too much for this lazy rascal to carry conveniently for two minutes. (turning a little up stage) Pons! where's Sergeant Pons?

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Here!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Very good! (seeing Plumeau) What not gone yet?

sp.speaker: Plum.
sp.p: I'm going. (as he exits, R.) Here's manners!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: The Countess is right. An army is nothing without a head, nor a house without a master—women are all very well, but there's no discipline—no drill—no subordination. (looking cautiously around) Sergeant!

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: General?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Give me a pinch of snuff.

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: 'Gainst orders.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Whose orders?

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: The Commander-in-Chief's—she don't like snuff.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Give it me, rascal! (handling cane) Give me the box! (he takes box from Sergeant, and is about to open it, when a noise is heard at back—hastily) There's somebody coming! It's the countess! Take back the box, do you hear, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: It's only Master Felicien.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: De-licious! I promised not to carry a box myself—so you carry it for me.

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: To think that a man as I've seen face a whole park of artillery without a quiver of the eyelid should give up all his pleasant habits, because—

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Silence!

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Yes! mon General!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Felicien, did you say?

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Looking at the flowers with Monsieur and Madame Molasse.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: The grocer and his wife! Sap-r-r-ris-ti!

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: 'Gainst orders.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: What's 'gainst orders?

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Swearing—You told me to remind you.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Bah! No snuff—no smoking—no swearing—what else is there in life worth living for?

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Nothing!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Silence!

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Yes! mon General.
sp.stage: (a noise of falling flower pots heard in conservatory, then enter Felicien Doucet, Monsieur and Madame Molasse, and Copernicus Kopp—Molasse and his wife in exaggerated rural costume, the former carries in one hand a plant, in the other a broken flower pot)

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: 'Twas your fault, Madame Molasse; if your confounded dog hadn't got between my legs—

sp.speaker: Mad. M.
sp.p: My dog? for shame, Molasse; there's not a person who hears his voice but says, “That's not a dog but a duck.”

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: I'd a dog once of just the same breed, he bit everybody—he was always mad.

sp.speaker: Mad. M.
sp.p: Mad?

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: General, allow me to introduce to you Monsieur Copernicus Kopp, an amateur astronomer, in correspondence with all the learned societies of Europe.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: Only press of business has hitherto prevented any of those distinguished bodies from answering his letters.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: A would-be prophet, who searches among the stars for reasons why everybody should be miserable on earth.

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: Good morning, General, if any morning can be good after such a night.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Night! it was a beautiful night.

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: Beautiful! with the tail of the dragon crossing the house of Mars? (with sudden fervour) I hope you're well, General.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Never better in my life.

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p:
Ah! that's a bad sign. It's an awful thing to feel
well sometimes; now there's Molasse, I've no doubt he feels well too?

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: Very well!

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: It's very sad, very—but such omens arn't sent us for nothing. (to Molasse) There was a friend of mine, about your build, only you're shorter in the neck. Kopp, he says to me one morning as merry as a cricket, I can't tell what's come over me, I never felt better in my life. (glancing at General) I didn't say anything to discourage him at the time, but of course I expected the worst.

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: Lor!

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: And sure enough it came.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: What came?

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: Apoplexy, that very night—dreadful!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: A cheerful person.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: Very. I don't know what we should do without him, he foretells all our misfortunes; not a morning passes but he's something new for us, as I say to Sophonisba, (indicating Madame Molasse) our Eden wouldn't be complete without Monsieur Kopp.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Eden?

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: It's the name we've given to our estate; for as I say to Sophonisba, all depends upon how you christen the article one offers for inspection.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: But an Eden should have trees.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: And we've a beauty, growing right in front of the house, shedding such a delicious gloom, that you can't see your hand in either of the rooms.

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: While the noise of rooks makes conversation impossible.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: But then the stillness of the night.

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: And the comfort of the stars.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: Certainly, our nights would be quiet enough if it weren't for two owls which have taken forcible possession of our pigeon house, and out of gratitude I suppose, hoot all night under our windows. But, then as I say, what does it matter? it's rural, and if it wasn't for such things, we shouldn't know we was in the country.

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: Bother the country, it's all very well to talk about, over a bunch of flowers in a bough-pot, but as I says the bulk ain't up to the sample. Persons of our property, should move in our proper spear, which isn't stuck in the middle of a garden.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: But think of a delicious little hermitage all covered over with ivy.

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: I'm none of your 'ermits; I don't approve of 'em.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: White curtains that reflect the sunlight.

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: With spiders crawling all over them.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Fresh flowers in the bedrooms.

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: Poisoning the air.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: And a faithful dog in the outhouse.

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: Who howls so all night that, you're disappointed if you wake without a sudden death in the morning.

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: Dreadful!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Thunder! Madame, since you'll have neither fruit nor flowers, what do you say to the vegetables?

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: Vegetables! We haven't a potatoe in the garden, but which from the cost, mightn't have been a pine apple.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: My potatoes! you should see 'em, General; so round and plump—such olive complexions and languishing eyes; each one promising an increase of family.

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: Molasse!

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: Sophonisba, I am silent.

sp.speaker: Fichu.
sp.p: Madame will be with you directly. (to Molasse) The gardener is in attendance to show the tropical plants monsieur desired to see.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: Them creepers which go about hanging themselves everywhere.

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: The owdacious ones, and justly named.
sp.stage: Madame Molasse, Molasse, and Kopp, follow Fichu up stage, and exeunt by conservatory.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.stage: (detaining Felicien as he is about to follow)
sp.p: Stay! (to Pons, who has remained standing like a sentry in background) Sergeant!

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: General!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Snuff box. (takes box—inhales a large pinch rapturously, then returns it to Pons) Now, right about face—march!

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Yes, mon General.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Why are you so sad, Felicien—heart touched; eh?

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Grazed by a passing shot perhaps—nothing more, sir.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Umph! Womankind's a strange invention, but a necessary one. Without some such contrivance there'd soon be an end to recruiting—no men, no soldiers—and without soldiers—thunder!—there'd soon be no France. Take a wife— take a wife—take a wife!

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: A wife? you're jesting.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p:
Morbleu! but the boy looks as scared as I did when I heard the whiz of an enemy's bullet for the
first time; but, as I soon got accustomed to the one, you'll cease to turn pale at the idea of the other.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Pardon me, sir; if I declare myself a convert to your opinions, so often expressed—I shall never marry!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: My opinions—what opinions?

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Surely, sir, I have heard you declare marriage to be the worst description of gaming, and one in which it was impossible to get a glimpse of your opponent's cards.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Umph!

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: That it was taking a life-lease of a house of which you've only seen the painted sign-board.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Bah!

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: And voluntarily placing yourself in a pillory to be pitied or laughed at by your friends.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Thunder!

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: It was a collar for the neck! It was a clog for the heels! and a man might deem himself fortunate if these were the only adornments.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Sa-pr-r-r-ri-sti! the rule I grant you, but there are exceptions—exceptions.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: I would fain believe so; but must decline to try the experiment. (gravely) I shall never marry.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Never's a long day, and I must own it grieves me, Felicien, when I hear it from your lips. (in a gayer tone) Come, come, such was not always your opinion. If report speaks true a pair of bright eyes had something to do with your long stay in Paris. (Felicien starts) Though you have kept their owner's name a secret—even from me.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: I pray you, sir.
sp.stage: (his voice falters and he turns slightly round)

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.stage: (with a tenderness in strong contrast to his usual brusque manner)
sp.p: Was the wound then so deep?—pardon me if I have probed it too roughly. Yet I do not despair but it will heal in time. Love is the rainbow that spans the horizon of youth and is made up of tears and smiles, as the other is of rain and sunshine—besides, a lover's quarrel—

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: It was no quarrel, sir—mine was a foolish dream, from which I have awakened.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: She was unworthy then of love.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Of such a love as mine, yes.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.stage: (gently, and placing his hand on Felicien's shoulder)
sp.p: My poor Felicien! tell me, who was the lady?
sp.stage: (as he asks the question, the Countess in elegant toilette, enters, R., unperceived)

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: I pray you, sir, let her name be as my love—a secret.
sp.stage: (the Countess who has only heard the last words, taps Felicien lightly on the arm with her fan)

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Love! and a secret! both matters that should have some interest for a lady. (with intention) Is it that Monsieur Doucet can have felt the passion?

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: He has; but is happy to number it among the things of the past.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: A happiness possibly shared by the lady.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.stage: (glances at her quickly and with bitterness)
sp.p: A woman, madame, is only happy when she suffers or makes others suffer. To suffer, when she loves—to inflict suffering, when she is loved.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: You are severe.
sp.stage: (as Felicien bows and goes up stage, she turns to the General, and with a bright coquettish smile, gives him her hand)

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Will you not break a lance, General, in defence of our sex?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: I—I, madame. (recovering himself, and bowing over hand which he raises to his lips—she watching Felicien, who is turning over books on table) Against the world, if permitted to wear your colours.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Well, there, then (she plucks flower from stand of plants) a rose, (giving it) but beware it has thorns.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: I already feel them—in my heart, madame.

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: Countess! come and help us to laugh; here's a Monsieur Copernicus Kopp prophecying the most dismal things. It seems all our stars are falling ones.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: He shall cast my nativity. (to Lacroix, as they go up stage) For when I was born—

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Venus must have been at her greatest brilliancy.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: And Mars in the ascendant. (aside and glancing at Felicien) If I could only make him jealous!—but, no! he is marble.
sp.stage: (they enter conservatory, then exeunt with company—sounds of merry laughter at back)

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Why do I stay!—this woman has no heart.
sp.stage: Crosses to canopy, R., to take up hat, as Plumeau enters L., introducing De Fauconville.

sp.speaker: Plum.
sp.p: I will inform Madame—

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: No occasion, (laughter at back) my friends have already joined her. I'll wait for them here.

sp.speaker: Plum.
sp.p: As monsieur will. (aside as he moves back towards door, his admiring eyes rivetted upon De Fauconville, who is surveying apartment through a lorgnon) There's style!—there's manner!—Paris in every gesture. (sighs heavily) Such a sight makes a man feel he's an exile.
sp.stage: (same moment Felicien turns and sees De Fauconville.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Baron de Fauconville!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Monsieur Felicien Doucet! (sneeringly) Though where the body is we may expect the shadow.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Monsieur de Fauconville, when in Paris I warned you to jest no further upon this subject. I repeat that warning here.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: I mean no jest; so bright a planet should have many satellites—has had many— so we need not be jealous of each other.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Enough, sir. If I could not doubt the information you forced upon me—one privilege at least was left me.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: What was that?

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: To despise the informer.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: I ought to be angry; but that I can make allowance for the irritability of a deceived and disappointed lover. Painful as it was for me to dispel the soft mirage of love, yet, for once, I felt called upon to play the part of a Mentor, and point out the desert beneath.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: And your presence here?

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: As easily accounted for as your own. When half dead with ennui at the neighbouring watering place of Eaudouce, I learnt by accident that the Countess Beauregard was our neighbour; and so a party of us, all Parisians, set out en masse upon a voyage of discovery, to find by what magical influence the most charming coquette of all Paris had been transformed into a shepherdess.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: And your search—

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Is already rewarded. (bows) I too am an Arcadian!

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.stage: (laughing, and indicating by a gesture the approaching company)
sp.p: Oh! in charity! let us not disturb this Paradise which seems complete in all things.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Even to the serpent among the flowers.
sp.stage: (he draws quickly back, so as to remain unobserved, as the Countess, the Baroness d' Antin, Mesdames d' Aumont, Du Helder, St. Roch, and Molasse come down stage, accompanied by M.M. Decourcelle, d'Fayolles, Volnay, Molasse, and Copernicus Kopp)

sp.speaker: Baroness.
sp.p: Only think, dear, of our disinterring you in this manner?

sp.speaker: Volnay.
sp.p: Just at the time, too, that we were bored to death by that monotonous sea, and were praying for a new sensation.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.stage: (with a constrained gaiety that covers a vexation)
sp.p: How was it you discovered this humble retreat?

sp.speaker: Baroness.
sp.p: It's a discovery we owe to Horace de Fauconville.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: De Fauconville!

sp.speaker: Volnay.
sp.p: Who, like another Columbus, lighted on a new world just as we were beginning to tire of the old one.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Let us hope the invaders are welcome.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: This man again! (aloud) In these primitive regions our doors are open to all.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: She receives him with a smile. Oh! woman! woman!
sp.stage: (he throws himself into fauteuil, L. 2 E., concealed from the company by stand of flowers, though visible to audience)

sp.speaker: Baroness.
sp.p: Nothing so delicious as the country. I could live in it for ever—that is, for a week or two—to picnic among the ruins—there are always ruins—to walk by moonlight—it's always moonlight in the country.

sp.speaker: Madame du H.
sp.p: Charming!

sp.speaker: Madame St. R.
sp.p: Dee-lightful!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: So retired—so quiet.

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: Quiet!—ask Molasse! We came into the country in search of solitude; but unless we're always making a noise we get no peace.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: It's rural.

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: But not comfortable: and as for privacy, we can't sit down to our tea, but—boo!—a cow comes and thrusts her head in at the window.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Beautiful!—who can doubt the genuineness of the milk when the cow herself condescends to look after it.

sp.speaker: Baroness.
sp.p: New milk and eggs—delicious!

sp.speaker: Madame du H.
sp.p: Charming!

sp.speaker: Madame St. R.
sp.p: Dee-lightful!

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: Eggs!—that's another mistake. I bought a hen the other day, warranted a good layer; so naturally expected she would supply the family—we're only six. Well, she does nothing of the kind—quite the contrary.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: She gave us an egg pretty regularly at first, but since I engaged a boy to look after her she lays nothing but shells.

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: You'll find them all in your star—I've been casting your nativity—signs all bad—dreadful!

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: Fiddlesticks!

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: It's not your fault. You were born in a wrong house.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: I was born in the house of Molasse and Co., under a most respectable sign, and my father—

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: Don't talk of fathers, they're only secondary causes —the planets are the primary.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: The deuce they are! If any such planets enter my house—

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: Molasse!

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: Sophonisba, I am silent!
sp.stage: (as they move up stage, De Fauconville speaks aside to Countess)

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: A word—I would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: I will speak with you.
sp.stage: (the Countess has drawn slightly out of earshot of the rest of the company, who, scattered about in groups, are examining the decoration, &c. of room—she faces De Fauconville with a high proud look, her hand resting upon the stand of flowers, L., behind which Felicien is seated)

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Speak on, sir.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: We parted in Paris to meet no more; accident has reversed that decision, and I am again at your side. (his voice softens) Clare, dear Clare!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Have a care, or—

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Do you have a care! (glancing quickly round, he leans towards the Countess, and speaks in a mocking whisper) By quitting Paris you thought to escape me. (he laughs) Folly! I am your shadow, Clare Beauregard.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.stage: (in a low voice, and leaning as for support against stand)
sp.p: Will no one rid me of this man?
sp.stage: (Felicien, still unperceived, has risen as about to leave his place of involuntary concealment, when Julie d'Aumont crosses to Countess)

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: Do not forget your wager—(with alarm) but how pale you are—you are ill!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: It's nothing; nothing, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Some sudden fear—a souvenir perhaps.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.stage: (raises her head proudly—her flashing eyes fixed on his face)
sp.p: You are mistaken. I have no fear. (she sweeps past him, and takes C. of stage—her manner as she addresses Guests is very bright and sparkling) Baroness, you have not sufficiently admired my flowers. In bidding you all welcome, I did so on the understanding that ennui should be left at the door.

sp.speaker: Volnay.
sp.p: The reservation was superfluous: ennui died as we crossed your threshold.

sp.speaker: Madame du H.
sp.p: Charming!

sp.speaker: Madame St. R.
sp.p: Dee-lightful!

sp.speaker: Baroness.
sp.p: You are queen regnant, dear.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: And shall use the royal prerogative—a yawn, eternal banishment—a sigh, the crime of lése Majesté, at least.
sp.stage: All laugh and applaud, then exeunt through conservatory— Baron remaining down stage—as the latter speaks, Felicien moves from behind the stand of flowers.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: No fear, she says! (his face darkens, and his voice changes) She braves me, then! Rests upon her innocence, perhaps. (he laughs) A broken reed! a broken reed!—with such proofs as I hold, the world, her world, will not hesitate to condemn. Marriage is out of the question; for, though forgiveness is part of a lover's creed, Felicien Doucet has only to know that those papers still exist.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.stage: (who now stands close to Baron, touches him lightly on the arm)
sp.p: For him to demand them again.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Monsieur Doucet still here! (recovering his sangfroid) Delighted to have again the pleasure.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: I demand of you, Baron de Fauconville, those papers which you promised me to destroy.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: You demand them, and by what right?

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: By the right which belongs to every man who believes a woman to be falsely calumniated, and knows her to be defenceless!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Falsely! you cannot doubt the proofs I offered?

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: I do!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Your reason?

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Their being offered, and by you!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Young man, for a lesser insult I have exacted a life—yet I would fain make some allowance for blighted hopes. You are not the first, nor will you be the last who has been the creator of his own angel and borrowed wings from heaven to bestow them on a creature of clay.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Enough, sir! I have not now to learn the power of a slanderous tongue, so deadly in its venom that a whole life of purity and truth cannot obliterate the momentary stain.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Ah! I see. The country air is dispelling the smoke of the town. (laughs) Birds, flowers, and sunshine all invite to love, no wonder we tune our guitars.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: No jesting, sir!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Chut! the ladies.

sp.speaker: Baroness.
sp.p: A beautiful collection!

sp.speaker: Madame du H.
sp.p: Charming!

sp.speaker: Madame St. R.
sp.p: Dee-lightful!

sp.speaker: Volnay.
sp.p: Really nature, you know, is not so bad after all, if 'tweren't for the exertion, the fatigue, and—and so forth.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: For shame! to be wearied with everything is now so much the fashion, that to be satisfied with the world we live in, is to proclaim oneself out of it.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Volnay is right—our modern life is too exhausting.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: We talk of exhausting life as the peasant accused the ass of drinking up the moon when its reflection disappeared with the water. Our dulness grows out of ourselves and is apart from the active world around us. Look at our young men for instance, who profess to be tired of life before they have properly opened their eyes upon it. For enthusiasm they have substituted indifference—for, eloquence a drawl— for intelligence (laughing and throwing wide her arms) a blank!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: And the remedy—where is that to be found?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: In action! like Demosthenes I exclaim—action! action! action! till our Sybarites cease to complain of a crumpled rose leaf; and act the Stoic and the hero at home as well as they have done abroad.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: And she can speak thus—this man must lie, or—

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.stage: (as she passes Felicien, touches him lightly on the arm with fan)
sp.p: You dine with us to day, Monsieur Doucet? You uncle has promised.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Impossible!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: A previous engagement?

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: I have other engagements.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.stage: (with hauteur and moving a little down stage)
sp.p: As you will. (aside) I will punish him for this.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.stage: (as he moves up stage speaks aside to Baron who is leaning carelessly against statue)
sp.p: We shall meet again, sir.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: When and where you please.
sp.stage: (as Lacroix appears on threshold of conservatory and comes down stage Felicien exits, L.—Lacroix is in full dress— he wears his cross and other decorations—his air that of a military Grandison of the old school—there is a general titter as the ancient beau comes down stage, and with a low bow presents the Countess with a bouquet)

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Madame! where nature has been so prodigal of loveliness, I dare scarcely hope a favourable reception for her meaner beauties.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I thank you, General.
Felicien gone! (aloud) You flatter, General.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: I speak a truth that would appear a flattery only to those who do not know you. (he starts as his eyes rest accidentally upon De Fauconville, who is still leaning against statue) Pardon me, madame! (with agitation) but —the name of that gentleman?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: The Baron De Fauconville—shall I introduce you?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: An introduction is unnecessary.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: You know him?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: We have met.

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: We shall lose the sunset.

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: Remember our wager. (to De Fauconville) your arm, Baron.
sp.stage: (all go up stage, and out by conservatory, with the exception of the Countess and Lacroix—the latter stands rigid as a statue, his eyes following De Fauconville)

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: General, I have a question to ask you.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.stage: (starts as one awakening from a reverie)
sp.p: Madame! I—(bows) Ask me a hundred, I shall be but too happy to reply.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Is it true that your nephew returns to Paris next week?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: To-morrow, madame!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: To-morrow? you surprise me.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Egad! he surprised me—sick of inaction I suppose, and I can't blame him, for when I was his age, I'd smelt powder, and knew what it was to give and take a sabre cut; though, for the matter of that, I think that my Felicien has been wounded.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Wounded!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Shot through the heart, madame, by that scoundrelly young rifleman, Sergeant Cupid. Been jilted by one of those coquettes, who, cat-like, lacerate while they play.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I know our sex finds but little favour with General Lacroix.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Madame, I—I—(as she turns slightly away he wipes his forehead) Then—(aside) I'd sooner face a cavalry charge than her eyes—each glance is a bayonet thrust.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.stage: (opening and shutting fan without looking up)
sp.p: And Monsieur Felicien has never mentioned the name of this lady?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Not he—the rascal is as close as an oyster. The wound is but green as yet though, for whenever I attempt to use the probe, he winces, as I did when first—

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Then you questioned him?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: I might as well have questioned Sergeant Pons, who answers only in monysyllables; but pouf! at the first rough shock in life these young fellows cry out that their hearts are broken. In such matters there's no cement like time.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: And your advice to him?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Is to marry—one nail drives out another—it's the only way to out-manœuvre the enemy.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: You think he will adopt your counsel?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Sure of it. Meanwhile I shall order him off to Italy, nothing like change of scene to cure such a heart disease.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Quit France?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Madame, I love Felicien—love him as a son; and I cannot bear to know his life embittered through the arts of some frivolous coquette.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Perhaps you judge too harshly; are you certain the fault lies with the lady?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: I am certain there is no fault in Felicien.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Keep Felicien at home, General. Cease to live like a hermit—throw open your doors—invite your friends—give balls—fêtes—it's change of society that's wanted, not change of scene.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.stage: (who has listened in a growing and ludicrous alarm)
sp.p: Balls! Fêtes! Turn my house into a caravanserai? Impossible. (aside) Thunder! What would Pons say?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Why impossible?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: At my age habits have become a second nature; our prejudices stiffen with our joints.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: At your age, general? Are men at fifty then so very old?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: No, madam; but old fellows of sixt—(he suddenly meets her eyes and stops abruptly) I am over fifty—a year or so.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: You'll induce Felicien to stay with us—(correcting herself)—with you?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.stage: (taking her hand, but immediately releasing it)
sp.p: How can I sufficiently thank you for the interest you take in him?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: In him! in you! It is in you I take an interest. (looking down) I would not see you left utterly alone.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: There's always Pons.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.stage: (change of manner to that of Pons and saluting)
sp.p: Yes, mon General! (laughing, and with an air of great simplicity) But how is it you never married?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Sap-r-r-ris—(a gesture on part of Countess stops the remainder of oath) I lacked the courage, madame.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: What! beat a retreat before you have faced the enemy? (archly) The face must—needs be very terrible.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: I offered battle once, though; but just as the enemy was ready to capitulate—

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: She changed her mind.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: No, madame, I changed mine. I met the lady at a ball, and fell in love with her beautiful hair. It was the most beautiful hair I ever saw—(glancing at Countess) with one exception; and when the dance was over it had twined itself so tightly round my heart, that it left me only breath to whisper my love in her ear; and at parting a gentle pressure of her hand told me that I might hope. My leave of absence expired on the next day. I determined to bring affairs to a crisis, so the morning saw me at her gate. There was no need of ceremony, for her father and I had served together in Algiers. I crossed the lawn and entered—unannounced—the breakfast room. To my astonishment, Sophie—her name was Sophie—was there and alone.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: And you proposed in due form?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: I did nothing of the kind—for, in place of my charmer of the previous night, I beheld a tame, expressionless girl, with a head like a gigantic firework; her beautiful hair had all disappeared, and in its place I saw only a forest of papers the very rustling of which haunted my dreams for months after.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: And that was the only cause?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Madame! the illusion was gone, and marriage stood before me in its blank reality. Her beauty was not for the domestic eye, but was only brought out from its cases and papers with the robes and jewels and other adornments. I stammered something—an adieu of some kind, and fled. Thunder! having witnessed the cooking—I'd no longer an appetite for the dish.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: A soldier! and lay down your arms after one defeat?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: I confess the enemy too strong for me. Why, the very shops—and I studied them well when in Paris, gave me a glimpse into the depth of the enemy's strategy, and I recoiled in terror. And ever afterwards, if I found my resolution melting away before the fire of a pair of bright eyes, I strengthened myself with the reflection that, perhaps, after all my heart had been set beating and my sleep disturbed by attractions which were derived from the bone of the whale and the tail of the horse. Ah! madame, our modern beauties defy Time, and with reason, for they have an inexhaustible arsenal in the toilette.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Then you've resolved never to marry?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Nev—(he stops abruptly) Who would marry an old fellow like me?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Very many, I'm sure.
sp.stage: (she averts her face and laughs—taking fan)

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: What a woman! If I dared! but no, I'd sooner attack Gibraltar.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I will gain my wager for the credit of my sex, and (with bitterness) to punish Felicien.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.stage: (aside, as Countess moves towards small table, on which is some embroidery in work basket)
sp.p: No coquetting there. Ah! if Felicien had only met such a woman.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I'm afraid, General, you men speak against women, as servants abuse their masters, and mistresses, trembling the while lest they should be overheard, and thereby lose their good opinion.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: I would not lose yours, madame, not to be made a Marshal of France—this little hand—

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Well?—(Lacroix drops her hand in great confusion) What do you want with my hand?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Nothing, madame, but—(exploding) Sap-r-ris—!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Fie! General; that makes the third great sounding oath I've heard in five minutes.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: True, madame, true. (desperately) It's all that rascal Pons. If I don't swear at him, he will have it that I'm ill, and immediately sends for a doctor—but—(he has taken her hand again—aside) My heart beats faster than a roll of drums, from a dozen regiments.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Have you any favor to ask me?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: A myriad!—that is, one for myself—for Felicien.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: For Felicien!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: If he could only have such an adviser ever near him. (she starts slightly) as a friend; as—as—an aunt, say. (Countess bends over embroidery, to conceal her laughing. Lacroix continues, each moment growing more confused and empressé) He would remain with us for ever—no, no, I don't —that's not what I mean—not for ever; but till he'd found such another, which is impossible. (exploding) Sapr-r-r-ris-ti!! madame! I adore your sex—that is (catching the Countess's laughing gaze) I would, were all women—

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.stage: (pausing in her work with pretty astonishment)
sp.p: Surely, General, you are rehearsing a part. I fear you too, have caught this heart disease; it must be in the air, it's so infectious.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Pardon me, if—

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Pray continue; but first tell me the happy fair one's name.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Her name? Morbleu!
sp.stage: (he seizes her hand and drops suddenly on his knees, as he does so the Countess with a little scream rises as quickly to her feet)

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: You've broken my silk.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Madame, I—

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I see Julie peeping—I shall win! (she takes skein of silk from basket, and placing one hand on Lacroix's shoulder, prevents him from rising) At least repair the damage you have done. (placing silk quickly over his hands) You can talk while I wind. (she commences to wind off silk) But not if you look in my eyes so.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Your eyes! Madame, do but look in mine, and read my heart—I love you, and am—

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.stage: (rising quickly and casting at the same time some of the loose silk about him)
sp.p: A lion caught in the toils!
sp.stage: (she holds up in triumph the slender threads which encompass her prisoner—at the same moment a peal of merry laughter resounds at back, and Julie D'Aumont, Fauconville, and the Guests appear on threshold of conservatory)

sp.speaker: Julie.
sp.p: A triumph of Cupid!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Hercules at the feet of Omphale!
sp.stage: (Lacroix, who has risen slowly to his feet, stands erect and silent, his brow contracted, and his look full of a stern menace as he gazes around—before this high proud glance the laughter ceases, and the intruders fall slightly back)

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.stage: (with calm dignity and turning to Countess)
sp.p: I am content to have been deceived, it is a just penalty for my blindness and folly; but this, and this, (touching the cross of honour and other decorations on his breast) might have pleaded with you, and prevented me from becoming the amusement of your guests. (the Countess is advancing, but he waves her back, then holding up hands, about which still cling the filaments of silk) Spare me further jesting; you see the net is broken.
sp.stage: (he shakes the threads disdainfully from his fingers, and moves up stage, as he does so the Guests, awed by his dignified bearing, fall back with involuntary respect, all but De Fauconville, who stands in his way still laughing —in a moment the hand of Lacroix rests upon his arm, which he compresses with a grip of iron)

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: When we next meet, Baron de Fauconville, the mirth will not be all on your side; for the present, the jest's with you. (he hurls De Fauconville disdainfully aside, and passes up stage—on threshold of conservatory he again pauses, and turns to Countess, who stands down stage, R. overwhelmed with shame and confusion, her eyes bent on the ground) Madame la Comtesse Beauregard, I take my leave. (he bows) But the battle is not over, and I may yet have my revenge.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: Scene.—Semi-interior room in the house of General Lacroix, opening upon a verandah overgrown with creeping-plants in flower; light pillar supports; a lawn beyond, with shrubbery. In verandah, and on lawn, orange trees in tubs; in distance a beautiful landscape; in extreme distance the sea, flecked with sunlight and dotted with sails. The room itself plainly but solidly furnished. In conspicuous places large busts of the Napoleons I. and III.; the walls decorated with plans of fortifications, &c. and arms (modern) of various kinds; a large copy of David's picture, Napoleon crossing the Alps, over chimney. Any other military pictures can be hung about, so as to add to the character of the mise-en-scene—doors R. and L.

Lacroix seated near table, down stage, a newspaper is at his feet, as if fallen from his hands, which rest listlessly upon his knees; his whole appearance that of one lost in a deep and painful reverie; he is in undress, his whole aspect entirely changed from that in Act I. Sergeant Pons up stage, L., brushing uniform.

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Here's nearly an hour he's been like that—the newspaper unread—the coffee untouched. (brushing) All night he was pacing his room, to and fro, never stopping, like a sentry in front of the enemy's lines —and Master Felicien too, just as wakeful. Each thought he was the only one on the alert, in the house; but old Pons was on duty too; backwards and forwards, from one door to the other, listening to'em—thousand bayonets! it's been a bad night for all. (brushing viciously) Hang the women! I never met one yet as was good for much, except Fanchette the Cantinière, and she was never sober but twice in the week.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Sergeant Pons.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Be off with you.

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Where to?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: The devil!—anywhere—and don't come back again. (rising) Leave me.

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Leave you?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Find another master. Go.

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.stage: (with startling vehemence and striking fist on table)
sp.p: I won't.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Mutiny.

sp.speaker: Pons
sp.p: I don't care what you call it, but I won't go.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: You won't?

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: I won't! (with feeling) I didn't leave you when you were surrounded by a dozen Austrians at Wagram; and, when I did go away at Waterloo it was with you on my back, and a sabre cut on my forehead. I didn't leave you then, (fist on table) and I won't leave you now; just because—because—(his voice falters—he wipes eyes with coat-sleeve) I should like to know what you'd do without me to take care of you?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.stage: (drawing himself stiffly up, and in voice of command)
sp.p: Pons!

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Yes, mon General.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Embrace me!

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Embrace me!

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Yes, mon General
sp.stage: (he embraces Lacroix, then, as he again draws back wipes his eyes—Lacroix taps him good-humouredly on the shoulder)

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Pons—I've been an old fool!

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Yes, mon General.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.stage: (throwing himself into chair and speaking as to himself)
sp.p: Ah! each time an old man's heart beats too quickly he suffers for it, and it's right that he should suffer. (pushing aside coffee) Pons, bring me some water.

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Water?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: And cognac.

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Good!
sp.stage: (goes up stage and returns with bottle and glasses which he places on table—then drawing snuff-box from pocket places it beside them)

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Strange that I should meet De Fauconville under her roof, and that for the first time. (mechanically taking up snuff-box) Pons, how long is it since we were in the depôt at Rouen.

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Ten years.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Just ten years. With him conscience has not added a line nor deepened a wrinkle.
sp.stage: (Pons approaches softly and places an Algerine pipe in Lacroix's hand as it hangs listlessly over arm of chair)

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Bah! he has no conscience—no heart. (he raises pipe to his lips and begins to smoke unconsciously, till raising his eyes he becomes aware of Pons who is giving way to every grotesque expression of satisfaction) What are you laughing at, you old gunstock?

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: That's better than a woman, anyhow.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: What do you know of woman?

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p:
I ought to know something, I married sixteen of 'em,
and all deceived me. They're alive and can't deny it. I took a new one in every country we passed through, and—ventre bleu! la grande armee went round the world.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: There, there—let me hear no more of it. (half aside) I was blind.

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Of course you were. Any one else would have seen with half an eye that poor Master Felicien was dying with love for her.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.stage: (starting to his feet with a cry)
sp.p: Felicien! My Felicien!—are you mad?

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: But being more modest than his uncle, hadn't, I suppose, the courage to speak out. So she, being over head and ears in love with him—

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Speak out, man—what?

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Plays the old fool against the young one. (smiting knees) Now the murder's out.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Go!
sp.stage: (he waves his hand to Pons, who startled by the effect of his words, stands irresolute)

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Pardon, mon General, if—

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Go—go! I am not angry, but I would be alone.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: It's all clear to me, now! My poor boy—my poor boy! I—I—
sp.stage: His voice fails him and he lets his head sink upon his hands which rest on table—at the same moment the Countess Beauregard appears, in morning walking dress, from shrubbery at back.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I've managed to escape from those tiresome people at last. I've not a moment to lose. I must see the General to tell him all and trust for pardon to his generous nature. (coming further down stage, but without perceiving Lacroix) Fichu tells me that high words passed between Felicien and De Fauconville—they must not meet again—yet how to prevent it. My only hope is in— (she turns, and for the first time sees Lacroix, who has risen from his chair) The General!
sp.stage: (she is advancing towards him but pauses, checked by the coldness of his manner—he bows with a haughty politeness—his bearing very calm and dignified)

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: This visit, madame, is as unexpected as—

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Undesired. I know what you would say. (aside and looking anxiously round) Where is Felicien?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Knowing so much, may I ask your errand here?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: To solicit your forgiveness for an act of folly.
sp.stage: (she is again advancing, but he stays her by a gesture)

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: I pray you, madame, jest no further in this matter. It is for me to demand pardon.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: An old owl that would fain venture out into the sunlight among the younger birds, to blunder blindly in the unaccustomed glare, and then wend homewards with a broken wing. In all this there is matter for laughter, but none for pity.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Pity?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: You had another purpose in coming here!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I—

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Nay, we do not readily drop a jest so well conceived. Was it not to laugh once more at the foolish vanity that betrayed its owner into your silken net? Your friends! are they not in ambush out there? I pray you bid them enter—only, for some, there may still be danger in bearding an old lion in his den.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: General Lacroix, I am here alone. I came to own a fault and to solicit its forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: At my age, madame, a folly repented is a lesson gained. It is not, as in youth, when we reason upon our passions as a barrister studies his brief, to discover faults, and to excuse them. (he bows) I have said the victory is yours, only you must pardon me if I refuse to follow the car of the conqueror. (seeing the Countess's hesitation) Our interview is at an end.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Farewell, sir, I am sorry—(her voice falters, she moves to go up stage, then turns and speaks with a sudden firmness and energy) You love Felicien Doucet?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Love him! (with feeling) It is now six and twenty years since a dying sister placed her infant child's hand in mine. From that time Felicien Doucet has been my son. (with much emotion) Ah! madame, who would not value the legacy of those who, dear to us in life, seem yet nearer and dearer as they sleep in the silent tomb?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: And Felicien deserves your love! (checking herself) doubtless.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: It is my pride to believe it.
sp.stage: (there is a pause—the Countess's manner betokens much hesitation of purpose)

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.stage: (after regarding her attentively as she stands a little up stage, her eyes bent on the ground)
sp.p: Yesterday, I learnt for the first time that you and Felicien were old friends.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: We had met in Paris.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: It was at your house, madame, if I am rightly informed, that he first met this lady whose evil influence has so embittered his life!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Evil!
sp.stage: (she raises her head quickly and in her voice there is a return of the old hauteur)

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: What other name for that whose sad effects I daily see and feel?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: The fault then lies with her? (Lacroix is silent) Thus man ever decides; man who preaches the cant of chivalry, yet finds no echo to the ready words, in the strong egotism of his heart.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Madame!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Think you a woman's life is always that piece of conventionality, which man would make it? you draw a circle round her—narrow her sphere of action, and then declare her brain is weak; her thought a feather, and her heart a void!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Madame!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: This, and all this contained in that one word— coquette. Man claims all, usurps all but that narrow domain, in which we reign supreme. Society is woman's battle-field; and the coquetry that dazzles and confounds, is often but the glittering veil which woman's pride throws over a tortured heart.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: If all women spoke thus—

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: What! Would you look for a woman's heart upon her lips? we feel acutely; more acutely than man can feel; yet, are early taught it is a crime, to express either by word or look, the feelings of the heart. Concealment is the girl's first lesson—Nature is sent to school, to wear a backboard, and put a padlock on her tongue. Why wonder then with such a teaching, if we are hypocrites perforce, almost from the cradle to the grave.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: I pray you—

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Enough! enough! It was not for this I came. (her voice grows firmer, and she raises her head proudly) I love Felicien Doucet—yes—I love him! and it is to save him from an impending danger that I am here.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Danger to Felicien?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: You know Horace de Fauconville? (Lacroix hesitates) You do know him!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: I know him!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: You know then that he is without honour, as he is without heart—a man that would recoil from no act, however base—no vengeance, however deadly!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: All this I know!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.stage: (lowering her voice as in a shuddering fear)
sp.p: You know then the evil reputation that has protected him so long— that of a duellist, without rival; and as pitiless as skilful.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: No more, I pray you—no more, madame, upon this subject! (the Countess pauses, surprised) Speak of Felicien, and say in what lurks a danger to him.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: In his love for me!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: How a danger?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: De Fauconville has sworn never to spare a rival!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Rival? De Fauconville then is your lover—(with severity) a favoured one?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: No! I have been wrong—foolish; but the bright light of day is not more pure than I am.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Yet this man has a power over you!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: A fatal one! (with much emotion) I am still young —my past is but of yesterday—yet the persecution of this bad man has made my life a lengthened bitterness.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: And you so gay, so—

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Have early learnt the great secret of my sex—to clothe a grief in smiles, and hide as only women can, the sorrows of the heart.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Still this mystery.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: It is to explain that mystery I am here.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: You are pale, madame; (taking her hand) your hand trembles, if—

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Visitors.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Not visible.

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Too late. (points off) The enemy has passed the entrenchments.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.stage: (to the Countess who has risen—his voice full of kindness)
sp.p: You are agitated. (opening door, R.) I will join you in the library when I have got rid of these people.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I thank you—I—I must speak.
sp.stage: (she passes out, and as Lacroix re-closes door Madame Molasse, Molasse, and Copernicus Kopp appear at back and come down stage—exit Pons, door L.)

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.stage: (coming down to Lacroix in his usual raven-like manner)
sp.p: Poor Monsieur Felicien!

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: Poor creetur!

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: Poor young man!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.stage: (angrily turning from one to the other)
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: Last night I cast his nativity.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: For the hundredth time.

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: True; but each time with a different result. (drawing large handkerchief slowly from pocket) It's very sad!Madame M. and Molasse.It's very sad.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: What's sad?

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: Mars having entered the house of Venus, the young man is marked for a great misfortune—an early death—dreadful!

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: But you prophecied the same of Molasse.

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: And was disappointed—I confess it—the stars are ot infallible.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Gentlemen—madame, surely, it's time enough for the ravens to croak when the battle's fought.
sp.stage: (he goes a little up stage, they remaining down, gesticulating dolefully)

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.stage: (to Pons who, entering, L., crosses towards back of stage)
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Message from Master Felicien!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Good!
sp.stage: (he is turning again down stage when Pons, as he turns to go up stage again, speaks)

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: To Monsieur de Fauconville!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Ah! (seizing Pons by the arm) Give me the letter!

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Mon general!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: I will deliver it myself!

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.stage: (addressing Lacroix as he comes down stage)
sp.p: I'm always sorry to be the bearer of bad tidings—but when one takes to sweeping the heavens—

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: There's no end to the rubbish collected. Confine your predictions in future to those who have time and inclination to listen to them—Monsieur Molasse for instance.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: Thank'ee, general; but Monsieur Copernicus is too kind already—he's always bringing us something new in the way of a misfortune.

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: We'd no idea what a miserable world it was till he brought it home to us.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: We shouldn't know half our mishaps if it wasn't for him.

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: And he's so far to go to look for them.

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: It's always best to expect the worst.

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: But very distressing to one's nerves. We've all our proper spears, as I say to M., and I wish the planets would keep to theirs and leave us to ours.

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: Madame, I wish to be of service to all, and am but too happy to be able to announce their miseries to my neighbours.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: And ours have more than answered expectation— nothing has gone well with us since the planets became partners in the same concern; our systems ain't the same; the milky way has no effect on our cows; our geese are so poor, one would think they were authors and lived on the produce of their own quills; our eggs are no sooner laid than they're poached; and as for our chickens, they seem born with as many pips as an orange.

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: And, I suppose as we have no children, the measles have settled down into the pigs.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: But then if it wasn't for such things. we shouldn't know we were in the country; and, if we can only get a little grass to grow on the lawn, we shall soon be as green as our neighbours.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: You would see my garden, Monsieur Molasse. I have business, business of importance, but Pons will conduct you over it.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: Thankee, general! happy to return the accomodation. We haven't anything to show as yet, but the seeds take very kindly to the ground.

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: So kindly that they seem determined never to come out of it.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: I am sorry that business—

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: Business on a Friday! it'll be a bad business for somebody.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: You will find refreshments in the arbour.

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: Arbour! we've a beauty, if it was only waterproof; but all last spring, we was obliged to sit in it with umbrellas.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: But general, what does it matter? it's rural, and rain's refreshing; and as I say to Sophonisba, if ever we are blessed with an increase of family—we've none as yet, but—

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: Molasse!

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: Sophonisba, I am silent.
sp.stage: (they exeunt hurried out by Pons, C. to R.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: At last! (breaks seal of note) Pardon me, Felicien, my son! (glancing at note) A challenge, as I suspected—rash boy! (again glancing at note) coupled with a demand for certain letters. (he reads) “Which you have cruelly shown, with a view to compromise the reputation of a lady. If your hinted accusation be false, you are a villain! and if true, you are a coward.” Phew! (he whistles) It's well this fell into my hands. (going up stage) I must see this Monsieur De Fauconville, and—

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: No one on the premises? general desertion of the garrison? (saunters on C. from L., is in light and very elegant walking toilette; carries lorgnon in eye, and is smoking) Curious place—sort of bivouac, I suppose. (aside seeing Lacroix.) Ah! our military Corydon. (coming leisurely down stage) Good morning, general! must apologise for intruding unannounced; but finding your gates open—

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: No apology is necessary. The Baron de Fauconville was never more welcome.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: What the deuce does he mean? (aloud) Having a little business to transact with Monsieur Doucet, who, perhaps you know is an old acquaintance of mine—

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: I did not know it till this minute, but I think you and I may claim a still older acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Eh?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: You have no recollection of me?

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Not the slightest. My visiting list is a large one, and therefore I may be pardoned if I forget a face or two.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.stage: I never do. Yours, for instance, has been ever present to my memory since I first saw it—some ten years ago, and then only for a few hours.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: You flatter me.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Not at all. It may surprise you, doubtless, but united with a distinct remembrance of your face—I also possess as clear a knowledge of your character and personal attainments—

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: I suppose, general, you've been taking lessons of the astronomer, Copernicus Kopp. (smoking) May I ask you for a sample of your intelligence?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: You are one of those curious amalgamations unhappily but too often met with in society—a man of high breeding and refined manners. (Baron bows) The delight of women, and the envy of men! (Baron bows again) The polished shell of gentleman without the heart! A rouè without conscience! A gambler without honesty!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: How, sir!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: And a duellist almost without rival.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: You know that!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: I know you for one of those bravoes of society, who have elevated assassination into an art, and made of murder a science.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: And yet you dare!
sp.stage: (he is advancing with a gesture of menace, when Lacroix, drawing himself proudly up, stops him by a look, at the same time folding his arms upon his breast)

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Stop, sir! and let me remind you of our last place of meeting: it was in the wood of Couci, near Rouen.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Couci—ah!
sp.stage: (he starts—same moment Pons, unperceived by either, appears at second door, R. up stage)

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: I was second in a duel of which you were one of the principals. My friend was a young man, a mere boy. The quarrel was over a gaming table; he had accused you, Baron de Fauconville, and accused you with truth, of cheating.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: How!
sp.stage: (he raises his arm, but Lacroix seizes it as it descends, and puts him firmly back)

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: All in good time, Monsieur de Fauconville—at least hear out my story. The result was, as I have said, you met in the wood of Couci. The first fire was his—he missed—not from want of courage, but from lack of skill. You were more fortunate; with deliberate cruelty you placed your hand on that child's heart. “You are very brave,” you said, and there was a flush of pride upon his cheek. “Have you a mother?” you asked, and there were tears in his eyes as he answered, “Yes.” “I am sorry for her.” you added with a laugh, then took your place and shot him through the heart; yes, like a coward and an assassin, you shot him, through the heart.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: You shall answer this!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: All in good time, Monsieur de Fauconville. That boy was the only son of a widow; her husband had been my earliest friend, and when I saw her last hope lying dead— murdered!—upon the ground, I swore to kill you, Monsieur de Fauconville.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: An oath easily taken.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: And tardily kept. Your friends had hurried you away. Three hours after my regiment was under orders for Algiers. Ten years have elapsed since then, and at last we've met. (for a moment the duellist is cowed by the calm determined aspect of the old General, and stands confused and irresolute) I have also a demand to make upon the part of a lady—the Countess Beauregard.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Whose name it has been your endeavour to compromise by means of some letters, which—

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.stage: (with a resumption of his usual sneering sang-froid)
sp.p: Are here! (he taps breast pocket of coat) When I part with them it will be to my wife.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Your wife!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: I'm too poor to be generous; if the Countess marries again, it will be to but one person—myself.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Read, sir! (giving Felicien's letter) That note is addressed to you.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: And has been opened by you—(smiling) Really, general!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Read, sir! time presses.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: A challenge! (quietly refolding note) Is it the uncle or the nephew that is to open the ball?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Follow me!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p:
No—Upon second thoughts I shall
give Felicien the preference. This challenge bears a prior date to yours.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: This is folly.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: My dear general, it is quite the contrary. I have sworn that Madame Beauregard shall marry me or—no one— and I will destroy the possibility of her doing otherwise, that's all.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Villain!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Be just, general—be just. (re-opening note and holding it up) Felicien's is the prior right—and it is only at his request I will wave.

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Assassin!
sp.stage: (he strikes Baron—the latter staggers back a few paces—recovers himself—dashes down note, and, with a startling change of manner turns to Lacroix)

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Your weapons?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Swords.
sp.stage: (Pons who has listened to the preceding scene with much excitement, and a gesticulation both humorous and pathetic disappears into room R. 3 E.—and immediately re-appears with two small swords)

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: They're here!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Sergeant Pons will act as my witness.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Where is mine?
sp.stage: (Pons who has again gone up stage suddenly seizes upon Molasse and Kopp, who come on from behind, and brings them down)

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Here! I'll bring 'em after you.
sp.stage: (Lacroix and Baron exeunt, C. to R.)

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.stage: (seeing swords, starts back in great alarm)
sp.p: A duel!— not under the present aspects.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: Under no aspects at all—think of Sophonisba.
sp.stage: (they are about to run off different ways when Pons catching them by the skirts detains them)

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.p: Thousand bombshells! you've only to look on.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: Catch me coming into the country again for peace and quietness.

sp.speaker: Kopp.
sp.p: Or visiting one's friends on a Friday.

sp.speaker: Pons.
sp.stage: (pushing them off stage, C. to R.)
sp.p: Right about face!— march!
sp.stage: (as they exeunt, C. to R., the door R. opens, and the Countess enters nervously—she looks around her as with surprise)

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p:
I am sure I heard voices—and in dispute. (her foot touches note dropped by Baron—she picks it up mechanically, and is about to place it on table when her eyes rest upon it accidentally—she starts) To De Fauconville! and the handwriting
Felicien's! (with suppressed scream) A challenge! My worst fears are confirmed. (as overcome by a sudden faintness she sinks into chair) And I—I am the cause. (again glancing at note) It is close upon the hour appointed for the meeting. she springs to her feet—at same moment door L. opens and Felicien appears—with a cry she rushes towards him) Felicien! thank heaven! you are here!

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Clare! madame, pardon me if I feel some surprise at seeing you here.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Felicien! I would explain.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: I require no explanation. (glancing at clock) The time is passed for that.
sp.stage: (he moves to go up stage— the Countess throws herself before him)

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: You must not leave me thus! You shall not! You go to meet De Fauconville! 'Tis useless to deny it. See! your letter is in my hands.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: My letter! (bitterly) You know then the cause of quarrel?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I have learnt, and for the first time the reason of your estrangement—of your sudden departure from Paris —your coldness here—your—
sp.stage: (her voice falters and she pauses, overcome by emotion)

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Clare! Clare! It was on the very day, within an hour after you had listened to my declaration of love—listened with eyes that beamed as I then thought, a tender approval through their veil of tears, that Horace de Fauconville placed in my hands the avowal of your love for another—for him.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: You saw those letters?

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: I did! and knew the handwriting to be yours. They all spoke of a woman's love for one who—

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: A woman's love! a child's—a silly romantic child's. (speaking rapidly and with indignation) I was in my fifteenth year, when I first met the Baron de Fauconville, an accomplished man of the world; skilled in all those arts which turn the head of a foolish girl, whose only world had been her father's château, but whose young imagination had been fed on the bright day dreams of the romancist, and the poet. What wonder then that my vanity was touched by the simulated passion of this man, and that with all the imprudence of youth, knowing no harm, and therefore dreaming of none, I wrote some letters, undated, and bearing only the signature of Clare!

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: These letters he preserved, and, long after I had shrunk from his insidious approaches, as from the deadly fascination of a snake, he re-appeared to whisper in my ear a fearful menace!

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: A menace!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: To place those letters, undated as they were, in my husband's hand.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: The villain!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: My husband, advanced in years, violent in character, and jealous of even the suspicion of a stain upon his honour.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Why not have trusted in that honour to have defended yours, and have crushed the hydra-headed calumny in its birth?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I dared not. Oh! think, Felicien, I was a woman and alone, placed by my husband's name and fortune in a position which made me a special mark for jealous and envious eyes. I had no friend to advise me—not one—and shrunk from that fiery ordeal which even innocence cannot pass through unscathed. It was then I stooped to purchase—yes, I purchased with money the silence he refused to give.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: A folly—worse, a madness!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I have said I was alone. My husband was rich and generous, and it was long ere my purse was exhausted; but De Fauconville had also his demon—one as grasping and remorseless as himself—the demon of gaming. My money was poured out like water—the source grew dry—still he demanded more. “I have no more,” I said. “You have jewels,” he answered, and—and—(she pauses, her voice broken by emotion) Alas! who, among the many who pressed around my chair, saw, while they gazed upon the smiling coquette, the grim Medusa visage that was turning her heart to stone—the dark and threatening shadow ever at her side.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: But after the Count's death?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I turned with scorn and loathing upon the baffled fiend whose power was gone—gone, but only for a time; then you came, and—and—(she hesitates for a moment, then speaks with much firmness) In my love for you again he saw his triumph.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Your love!

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: My love.

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Clare! dear Clare!
sp.stage: (as he embraces her the clock strikes)

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: The hour!
sp.stage: (he moves to go up stage when the Countess again throws herself before him)

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: You shall not meet this man!

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Clare, Clare! would you stand between me and honour?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Between you and death! (she clings to him as he again attempts to pass) Felicien, in the name of all you hold sacred! in the name of our love!
sp.stage: (she sinks on knees still clinging to him)

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: I were not worthy of that love did I consent to live without honour.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Speak not to me of honour! To risk your life with such an adversary is no honour, but a shame. He will kill you, Felicien; he is without conscience as he is without heart. (she throws her arms round him) Felicien, you shall not go—your life belongs to me, your wife!

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: And against my wife the world shall hear no murmur of reproach. This viper must be rendered harmless. (he releases himself and goes quickly up stage) Have no fear but I will draw the sting.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Felicien!

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: Those letters—

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.stage: (suddenly appearing at back, C. from R.)
sp.p: Are here!!!
sp.stage: (he holds them up, at the same time concealing two swords behind his back which Pons, who now enters with Kopp, takes quickly from him as he comes down stage and exits with, door R. 3 E.)

sp.speaker: Felicien.
sp.p: And De Fauconville?

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.p: Will trouble this lady no more. He has quitted Normandy—(with emphasis) never to return!
sp.stage: Enter Molasse, C. from R., with Madame M.

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: And I shall follow his example; for it may be rural—but I'll be—(striking fist smartly in hand) if it's comfortable!

sp.speaker: Madame M.
sp.p: Molasse!

sp.speaker: Molasse.
sp.p: Sophonisba, I am silent!

sp.speaker: Lacroix.
sp.stage: (who has approached the Countess, who stands half shrinking, yet her eyes bent eagerly on his face)
sp.p: Madame! our battle is over—and, if an old soldier may be pardoned his boast, this is my Last Victory. (he bows with much respect as he places the packet of letters in her hand) My revenge is here!
